title: Projects
text:
arXiv Preprint | Code
I was recruited by Dr. Michael Fu to add health monitoring capabilities to the modular implantable stimulation platform that was invented by Dr. Kevin Kilgore, the “Networked Neuroprosthesis” (NNP). The NNP’s unique feature is that it consists of distributed battery, stimulation, and electromyography modules that are linked within the body by a network cable that carries power and communication signals. The NNP is under clinical trials and has been implanted in 7 people (30 planned) with spinal cord injury (SCI) and tetraplegia to restore motor functions including hand grasp, trunk stabilization, and standing transfer. Despite its impressive capabilities, the NNP currently lacks the ability to warn its users of autonomic dysreflexia (AD) events, which can lead to fatal blood pressure spikes (hypertension) in people with tetraplegia. My doctoral thesis is aimed at creating a new version of the NNP network cable that has an integrated blood pressure sensor to detect AD events. This sensor is optical which should

title: Projects
section: Data Analysis Of In Vivo Bladder Sensor
text:
Data Analysis Of In Vivo Bladder Sensor

arXiv Preprint | Code
While working at the APTC, I utilized MATLAB to properly analyze data resultant from an in vivo bladder sensor. I utilized these tools to properly categorize bladder activity (voiding) via the pressure sensor while also working to properly classify novel electrode data to attempt to learn more about the volume of the bladder. My works led me to be a a coauthor of a IEEE Sensors Journal paper titled, “Wireless and Catheter-Free Bladder Pressure and Volume Sensor” (Majerus, Cabal 2023).
Majerus et al., “A Catheter-Free Bladder Pressure-Volume Sensor.”

title: Projects
section: Data Analysis Of In Vivo Colon Sensor
text:
Data Analysis Of In Vivo Colon Sensor

arXiv Preprint | Code
While working at the APTC, I utilized MATLAB to properly analyze data resultant from an in vivo colon sensor. I utilized these tools to properly categorize multiple types of colon activity via both the pressure and electrode sensors while also working to properly classify each type of activity. My works led me to be a a coauthor and presenter of an IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Circuits and Systems, “A Flexible Implant for Multi-Day Monitoring of Colon Segment Activity” (Majerus, Cabal 2023)
Majerus et al., “Multi-Modal, Implantable Colon Activity Sensor.”

title: Welcome to my website!
text:
Github
  
  
    
     LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Welcome to my website!
My name is Dario Cabal, a graduate of Case Western Reserve University with my B.S in Electrical Engineering and a minor in Biomedical Engineering. On this website, I offer some insight onto my skill set, ongoing research, and publications.
My research interests span the development of state-of-the-art Application Specific Integrated Circuits (ASIC) design for implantable devices along with the the development and deployment of other implantable devices. And I already am listed as a secondary author on several publications relating towards implantable devices.
On this website, you will find a selection of my published works. You will also find news and updates on my current research projects, as well as information on upcoming events and conferences where I will be speaking. I invite you to explore my website and learn more about me and my pursuits. Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects.

title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.
